document_title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station
summary_full: A novel bacterial species, Cohnella hashimotonis, was identified from a sample collected from the International Space Station (ISS). This gram-positive, rod-shaped bacterium, designated F6_2S_P_1T, was isolated from the wall behind the Waste Hygiene Compartment. Phylogenetic and genomic analyses, including 16S rRNA, gyrB, Average Nucleotide Identity (ANI), and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH), placed it as a distinct species within the Cohnella genus, most closely related to C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli, which are typically found in plant environments. Whole-genome sequencing of F6_2S_P_1T, C. rhizosphaerae, and C. ginsengisoli revealed a shared set of 332 gene clusters unique to this clade. Functional predictions suggest metabolic capabilities related to carbohydrate and amino acid transport, transcription, and cell wall biogenesis. The study also characterized the phenotypic and chemotaxonomic features of C. hashimotonis, noting its ability to metabolize a wide range of carbon compounds and its specific fatty acid profile. The presence of C. hashimotonis on the ISS is hypothesized to be from plant growth experiments rather than human commensalism. The genome analysis did not reveal genes for antimicrobial resistance or virulence.
key_findings: A novel bacterial species, Cohnella hashimotonis, was isolated from the International Space Station (ISS).
Genomic analyses (ANI, dDDH, phylogenetics) confirm C. hashimotonis as a new species, distinct from other known Cohnella species.
C. hashimotonis belongs to a distinct clade within the Cohnella genus, sharing a unique set of 332 gene clusters with closely related species.
The strain exhibits a broad metabolic capability for carbon compounds and possesses genes for endospore formation and plant growth hormone production.
No genes for antimicrobial resistance or virulence were detected in C. hashimotonis.
The presence of C. hashimotonis on the ISS is likely due to plant growth experiments, not human commensalism.
future_research_fields: Investigating the role of C. hashimotonis in plant growth promotion in space environments.
Exploring the potential biotechnological applications of C. hashimotonis, particularly its carbohydrate-degrading enzymes.
Further characterization of the unique gene clusters found in the C. ginsengisoli clade.
Studying the survival mechanisms of C. hashimotonis in extreme ISS conditions.
Investigating the origin and transmission pathways of plant-associated microbes within the ISS environment.
conclusions: Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. is a novel bacterial species isolated from the ISS, characterized by phenotypic, chemotaxonomic, and genomic analyses. It belongs to a clade of Cohnella species primarily associated with plant environments, suggesting its introduction to the ISS via plant growth experiments. Despite its extraterrestrial origin, C. hashimotonis demonstrates resilience and potential utility, particularly as a plant-growth-promoting agent for future space agriculture.
impact_statement: This study identifies a novel bacterium from the ISS, expanding our understanding of microbial life in space habitats and highlighting potential candidates for supporting plant growth in future extraterrestrial missions.
